repnme.cdata!:
Georgia - Institution Building Credit,
            Rehabilitation Credit, First and Second Structural
            Adjustment Credits, First and Second Structural Adjustment
            Technical Assistance Credits, and Energy Sector Adjustment
            Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit conveys mixed results compared
            with the Implementation Completion Report's (ICR)
            ratings, as follows: while ratings concur regarding the
            Institution Building Credit (IBC), and the First Structural
            Adjustment Technical Assistance (SALTA) Projects of
            satisfactory outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, it downgrades the
            Rehabilitation Credit (RCP) project outcome from highly
            satisfactory to satisfactory, upgrading its sustainability
            to substantial; downgrades the Structural Adjustment Credit
            (SAL) Project outcome to moderately unsatisfactory, with
            likely sustainability, but with modest institutional
            development impacts; and, downgrades the Second Structural
            Adjustment Credit (SALII) Project outcome to unsatisfactory,
            and modest institutional development impacts. Ratings of the
            Energy Sector Adjustment Credit (ESAC) Project concur on
            satisfactory outcome and likely sustainability, but the
            audit upgrades institutional development impacts to
            substantial, and, on the Second Structural Adjustment TA
            (SALTAII) Project outcome is downgraded to moderately
            satisfactory, and modest institutional development impacts,
            although sustainability is also likely. Lessons indicate
            that Georgia's weak governance severely limits the
            country's ability to create conditions conducive to
            economic development, and the effective use of development
            assistance, and, that for a country which experienced
            economic collapse, it is incumbent that the Bank give high
            priority to prompt measures that can directly mitigate
            conditions for the poorest. Furthermore, turnover on the
            country team limited program effectiveness, diminishing the
            continuity of the program, and probably constraining the
            Economic and Sector Work (ES W) that was performed,
            suggesting a more robust, timely ESW program would have been
            beneficial to the design of the reform program, while the
            turnover among policy officials hindered reform progress.

repnme.cdata!:
Georgia - First and Second Structural
            Adjustment Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall assessment of the First and
            Second Structural Adjustment Credits (SACs) was
            satisfactory, having achieved its major objectives, with a
            sustainable likelihood. Among the key lessons learned,
            sustaining fiscal reform stands as a major factor in the SAC
            successful operations, for although fiscal reform can be
            hampered by external factors, such as the collapse of the
            Russian economy, with severe fiscal strains for Georgia, the
            country, nonetheless, was able to restore funds. However,
            further gains in resource mobilization should only be
            emphasized once tax compliance is achieved, for as revenue
            mobilization increases, it becomes more difficult to achieve
            incremental tax revenues. The lessons also suggest the
            advantages of a high level counterpart to support successful
            reforms, or resource mobilization. Likewise, certain
            specific measures in the Letter of Development Policy, which
            provided real power and credibility to both institutions,
            were equally advantageous. Credibility of legal status can
            be gradually built, as shown by the instrumental timetable,
            which helped meet prudential targets under the SACs. While
            the transfer of entities to the private sector, may be
            facilitated by vouchers, these may tend to concentrate among
            only a few, whereas a comprehensive listing, could provide
            better results. The benefits of trade liberalization were
            effectively emphasized under both operations.

            (GEORGIA,ARMENIA) - STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT,TF022072-STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT CREDIT,TF032957-EASTERN EUROPE

            (ARMENIA,GEORGIA) - STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT
5081020.majtheme: Rule of law,Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development,Economic management

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Structural
            Adjustment Credit Project is to consolidate stabilization,
            foster a strong and sustained growth recovery and reduce
            poverty.  The Government's reform program, supported by
            the project, aims at: 1) maintaining a tight monetary
            program supported by an improving fiscal position; 2)
            streamlining the Government sector and improving efficiency
            of public spending; and 3) inducing a rapid adjustment of
            the productive sector to new market signals.  Other
            objectives of the project are to: 1) provide budgetary
            support to maintain the level of critical public
            expenditures; 2) provide foreign exchange for the purchase
            of critical imports; and 3) provide a framework for
            financial assistance from other donor agencies.  The key
            reforms that the project will finance are: 1) removal of tax
            exemptions and strengthening of tax administration; 2)
            improvements in collection of energy payments; 3) changes in
            the provision and financing of social services; 4)
            restructuring of the pension system and social protection;
            5) acceleration of privatization; 6) restructuring of the
            financial sector; and 7) trade liberalization and trade promotion.
